**Michalson v. Nutting**, 275 Mass. 232.proposition: Under **Massachusetts law**, property owners have a duty to maintain **trees and vegetation within their control** in a condition that does not unreasonably endanger individuals lawfully using adjacent public ways.
**Michalson v. Nutting**, 275 Mass. 232.support_reasoning: The case concerns damage caused by tree roots to an adjacent landowner’s private property, not to users of a public way, and it holds that there is no liability in Massachusetts for such encroaching roots or branches. The court expressly states that the tree owner may use his land to grow trees and that the harmed neighbor’s remedy is self‑help (cutting roots/branches), not an action for damages or injunction. This directly contradicts, rather than supports, a claimed duty on property owners to maintain trees and vegetation to avoid unreasonable danger to others, and it says nothing about public ways.
**Michalson v. Nutting**, 275 Mass. 232.relevant_excerpt: “The principle involved is that an owner of land is at liberty to use his land, and all of it, to grow trees. Their growth naturally and reasonably will be accompanied by the extension of boughs and the penetration of roots over and into adjoining property of others… The neighbor, though without right of appeal to the courts if harm results to him, is, nevertheless, not without remedy. His right to cut off the intruding boughs and roots is well recognized… In this Commonwealth, there was no actionable nuisance and no right of recourse to equity.”

**Gifford v. Route 20 Associates**, 76 M.raw_text: **Gifford v. Route 20 Associates**, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 840 (2010)
**Gifford v. Route 20 Associates**, 76 M.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful pedestrian on the adjacent sidewalk, a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect and remove or repair dangerous conditions on property under his control, including diseased or cracked branches overhanging the sidewalk.
**Gifford v. Route 20 Associates**, 76 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a criminal OUI conviction and whether a pier constitutes a “public way” under G.L. c. 90, § 24. It does not involve premises liability, duties of landowners to pedestrians, or any discussion of inspection or maintenance of overhanging tree branches or similar conditions on adjacent sidewalks. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant owed a pedestrian a duty to inspect and remove or repair dangerous overhanging branches.
**Gifford v. Route 20 Associates**, 76 M.relevant_excerpt: In order to sustain an OUI conviction, the Commonwealth must prove that the offense took place “upon any way or in any place to which the public has a right of access, or upon any way or in any place to which members of the public have access as invitees or licensees.” G. L. c. 90, § 24(1)(a)(1). “Way” is further defined by statute to include “any public highway, private way laid out under authority of statute, way dedicated to public use, or way under the control of park commissioners or body having like powers.”

**Glenn v. L. & J. Corp.**, 149 Mass. 47.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful pedestrian on the adjacent sidewalk, a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect and remove or repair dangerous conditions on property under his control, including diseased or cracked branches overhanging the sidewalk.
**Glenn v. L. & J. Corp.**, 149 Mass. 47.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns stockholder rights, fraudulent misrepresentation, and corporate authority regarding trade names and business lines; it does not involve premises liability, pedestrians, sidewalks, trees, or duties to inspect and repair dangerous conditions on land. Nothing in the court’s reasoning or holding addresses a landowner’s duty to pedestrians or any duty related to diseased or cracked branches overhanging a sidewalk. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the stated negligence/premises-liability proposition.
**Glenn v. L. & J. Corp.**, 149 Mass. 47.relevant_excerpt: "The bill cannot be maintained unless it shows a duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, which can be enforced in equity. Such duty cannot arise from the relation of the parties as members or officers of corporations, but must be found, if at all, in the representations or promises alleged to have been made by the defendant to the plaintiff."

**Cutter v. City of Arlington**, 288 Mas.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to act on known warnings about the unsafe tree branch and by failing to have the tree examined or pruned by a competent arborist.
**Cutter v. City of Arlington**, 288 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns probate and construction of a will, payments for caregiving services, and setoff of a legatee’s debt against a small legacy. It does not address municipal tort liability, trees, warnings about unsafe branches, or any duty to have a tree inspected or pruned by an arborist. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about breach of duty regarding an unsafe tree branch.
**Cutter v. City of Arlington**, 288 Mas.relevant_excerpt:
There is no report of the evidence. At the request of the appellant the trial judge filed his findings of material facts. These must be accepted as true since they are not mutually inconsistent or plainly wrong.

The payment to Elizabeth G. E. King, a daughter of the testatrix, for services and expenses, is challenged. The finding is that these disbursements were proper and necessary for the comfort of the testatrix and that the daughter gave up a position as school teacher in order to take care of her mother, that the price charged was reasonable, and that she expected to be paid.

**Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.**, 319 M.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to act on known warnings about the unsafe tree branch and by failing to have the tree examined or pruned by a competent arborist.
**Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.**, 319 M.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landowner’s duty to act on known warnings about an unsafe tree branch and to have it inspected or pruned by a competent arborist. Carter v. Yardley is a products‑liability/negligence case about a perfume manufacturer’s duty to remote consumers and the abolition of the privity requirement; it does not involve premises liability, trees, warnings about hazardous conditions, or any duty to inspect or prune. Accordingly, it does not support the specific duty and breach described in the proposition.
**Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.**, 319 M.relevant_excerpt: "In principle, a manufacturer or other person owning or controlling a thing that is dangerous in its nature or is in a dangerous condition, either to his knowledge or as a result of his want of reasonable care in manufacture or inspection, who deals with or disposes of that thing in a way that he foresees or in the exercise of reasonable care ought to foresee will probably carry that thing into contact with some person, known or unknown, who will probably be ignorant of the danger, owes a legal duty to every such person to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him."

**Kent v. Commonwealth**, 437 Mass. 312.proposition: Defendant’s breach was the **direct and proximate cause** of Plaintiff’s physical injuries and economic losses.
**Kent v. Commonwealth**, 437 Mass. 312.support_reasoning: The case does address proximate cause, but it holds that the defendant’s conduct (the Commonwealth’s parole decision) was not, as a matter of law, the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries because intervening actions by the INS were a superseding cause. Thus, Kent v. Commonwealth is authority for the opposite proposition: that the governmental defendant’s breach was too remote to be the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Citing this case to show that a defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of injuries would misstate its holding.
**Kent v. Commonwealth**, 437 Mass. 312.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore turn to the issue of proximate cause on the plaintiffs’ claims of gross negligence. … Because the duty to prevent harm, and the risk created by MacNeil’s release, were transferred to a law enforcement agency that could lawfully be relied on to perform safely the responsibilities it had assumed, the element of proximate cause, which might otherwise have linked MacNeil’s release on parole with his harmful conduct in Leominster, was extinguished. Subsequent action by the INS releasing MacNeil in Massachusetts became a superseding cause of the harm he inflicted, relieving the Commonwealth of liability as a matter of law.”

**Jenkins v. City of Boston**, 199 Mass..proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was a reasonably foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to maintain the tree safely.

**Banagan v. SMG Food Serv., Inc.**, 70.raw_text: **Banagan v. SMG Food Serv., Inc.**, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 614 (2007)
**Banagan v. SMG Food Serv., Inc.**, 70.proposition: Defendant’s failure constitutes negligence under the principles set forth in **Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302, 364**, adopted in substance under Massachusetts law.
**Banagan v. SMG Food Serv., Inc.**, 70.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal procedure case about a vehicle stop, warrantless entry, search, and Miranda issues; it does not analyze negligence, civil liability, premises liability, or the Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302 or 364. The court’s reasoning concerns Fourth and Fifth Amendment / Massachusetts constitutional standards, not tort duties or adoption of Restatement negligence principles. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a defendant’s failure constitutes negligence under those Restatement sections in Massachusetts law.

**Alemeida v. Watertown**, 460 Mass. 552.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent conduct.
**Alemeida v. Watertown**, 460 Mass. 552.support_reasoning: This is a Massachusetts criminal homicide case dealing with severance, evidentiary issues, prosecutorial argument, and suppression of statements. It does not address negligence, compensatory damages, or any civil damages measure. Because the opinion never discusses what damages a plaintiff may recover in a negligence action, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about compensatory damages in Massachusetts negligence law.

**Roderick v. Brandy Hill Co., Inc.**, 3.raw_text: **Roderick v. Brandy Hill Co., Inc.**, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 948 (1994)
**Roderick v. Brandy Hill Co., Inc.**, 3.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent conduct.
**Roderick v. Brandy Hill Co., Inc.**, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the scope of recoverable compensatory damages at all; it addresses only whether the defendants breached a duty of care and thus could be found negligent. The court affirms summary judgment for the defendants because plaintiffs had no reasonable expectation of proving breach, so it never reaches issues of causation or damages. Therefore, this case cannot be authority for the proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence.
**Roderick v. Brandy Hill Co., Inc.**, 3.relevant_excerpt: "In sum, based upon the pleadings and verified materials presented to the motion judge, the plaintiffs have no reasonable expectation of proving that the defendants breached the duty of care owed the plaintiffs, an essential element of their negligence action."

G.L. c. 223, \u00a71.proposition: Venue is proper in **Berkshire County Superior Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §1, because the cause of action arose in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, and Defendant resides within this county.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a74.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, §4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

**Mass. G.L. c. 231, \u00a785**.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent conduct.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a76B and 6C.proposition: Award compensatory damages in an amount to be proven at trial, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, together with interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§6B and 6C;
